qas.question: Of what does Dvaita Vedanta theorize the existence?
To what entity is the Vedanta Vishnu similar in other religions?
How is the God of Dvaita different from that of Advaita in actions?
As what did the Dvaita school view dualism?
Who did the Dvaita school identify as the Supreme Being?
What theory claims there is one reality?
How is the Dvaita Vedanta Vishnu different from other religions?
Who has an impersonal role according to Dvaita?
What in Dvaita is only temporary?

plausible_answers.text: God takes on a personal role and is seen as a real eternal entity

qas.question: What distinguishes Advaita Vedanta from Dvaita?

context: <b5_0>Dvaita Vedanta<b5_0/> is a dualistic interpretation of the Vedas, espouses dualism by theorizing the existence of <a0_0>two separate realities<a0_0/>. The first and the only independent reality, states the Dvaita school, is that of Vishnu or Brahman. <b6_0>Vishnu is the supreme Self<b6_0/>, in a manner similar to <a1_0>monotheistic God<a1_0/> in other major religions. The distinguishing factor of Dvaita philosophy, as opposed to monistic Advaita Vedanta, is that <b7_0><b9_0>God<b7_0/> <a2_0>takes on a personal role<a2_0/> and is seen as a real eternal entity<b9_0/> that governs and controls the universe. Like Vishishtadvaita Vedanta subschool, Dvaita philosophy also embraced Vaishnavism, with the metaphysical concept of Brahman in the Vedas identified with <a4_0>Vishnu<a4_0/> and the one and only Supreme Being. However, unlike Vishishtadvaita which envisions ultimate qualified nondualism, the <b8_0>dualism<b8_0/> of Dvaita was <a3_0>permanent<a3_0/>.
